explanation: Globally: if a datagram is received on a network, it must not be broadcast on that same network
Globally: the IP layer must recognize both the broadcast address and its own address
Globally: if a datagram is not meant for the host, the host should discard it
Globally: if address is the broadcast address 255.255.255.255, the datagram must not be forwarded
Globally: the gateway should use normal routing procedure and send datagram to next gateway
Globally: the gateway should always consider itself a destination of the datagram
Globally: if a datagram is addressed to a connected network, it should be sent as a data link layer broadcast
Globally: the gateway should always consider itself to be a destination of the datagram
Globally: if a datagram is received on the network it's addressed to, it must not be forwarded
Always: if a command is received and there's an earlier command, then when processing starts, FIFO order must be maintained

ltl_formula: G ((commands_are_grouped & (rset_command_received | mail_from_command_received | send_from_command_received | soml_from_command_received | saml_from_command_received | rcpt_to_command_received)) -> (response_generated -> response_stored_in_buffer))
explanation: Always: when commands are grouped and any of the specified commands are received, responses should be stored in buffer rather than sent immediately
Always: when DATA command is received, positive response is issued if and only if valid RCPT TO addresses were previously received
Always: if server issues positive response to DATA with no valid recipients and receives empty message, then always never send any message to anybody
Always: responses to EHLO, DATA, VRFY, EXPN, TURN, QUIT, and NOOP commands must not be buffered
Always: if an unrecognized command is received, the response must not be buffered
Always: when TCP input buffer is emptied and pending responses exist, they must be sent immediately
Always: never make assumptions about commands that are yet to be received
Always: never flush the TCP input buffer or lose its contents under any circumstances
Always: when system issues a response, it should indicate (explicitly or implicitly) what command the response matches
Always: when counting mechanism is active, commands and responses must be counted and eventually correlated
Always: if client uses pipelining and command group is complete, all statuses associated with each command must be checked
